terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Flanders. Moderate elevation with Belgian countryside scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Belgian event. Rolling Flanders terrain with moderate organization and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Gravel des Flandres is a regional event in Flanders, Belgium‚Äîrolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Belgian countryside is nice, but the moderate organization and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional Belgian gravel race with Flanders rolling terrain. Worth it for Belgian/European cyclists. Not a destination race for international travelers.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Belgium/Europe‚Äîyes, it's solid. If you're international‚Äîthere are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For similar Belgian events: Houffa Gravel, Ardenne Gravel Stages.

logistics.food: Flanders has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Belgian Flanders rolling requires sustained effort.

prestige.explanation: This race barely exists in the gravel consciousness ‚Äî research turns up French events with similar names but nothing concrete for this Belgian version. No notable winners, no pro field, no YouTube coverage worth mentioning. It's riding on the Flanders name without earning the reputation.

race_quality.explanation: Hard to judge quality when basic race details are a mystery. The 65-mile distance with 3500 feet suggests decent planning, but without confirmed aid stations, cutoff times, or even verified course details, you're gambling on execution. Similar events like Flandres Charentaises deliver 'classiques √† l'ancienne' but this one's still proving itself.

experience.explanation: Belgium knows how to do cycling culture, even if this particular race is flying under the radar. The Flanders region delivers authentic cobbled roads and that 'esprit du tour des Flandres' atmosphere that nearby events promise. You'll get the real Belgian cycling vibe, just without the crowds or fanfare.

community.explanation: Belgian cycling communities are tight-knit and welcoming by default ‚Äî it's cultural DNA. While this specific race lacks the 'ambiance l√©gendaire' that established events boast, you're still tapping into a region where every local understands suffering on two wheels. Smaller field probably means better camaraderie anyway.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 200-400 riders, no data on field size or competitive depth, which tells you everything. Established events like La Breizh'Flandrienne show hundreds of participants across distance options, but this race isn't drawing those numbers yet. You're looking at enthusiasts and locals, not serious competition. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Belgian races typically run cheap ‚Äî similar French events charge ‚Ç¨7-‚Ç¨14, so you're probably looking at reasonable entry fees. The 65-mile distance gives you proper bang for your buck without the premium pricing of famous classics. Good value if the race actually delivers what it promises.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs ‚Ç¨60-100. Belgium isn't budget cycling territory ‚Äî accommodation and food costs add up fast in Flanders. No confirmed lodging strategy or parking details means you're figuring out logistics yourself. European travel expenses hit hard, especially when the race infrastructure isn't clearly established to help you navigate efficiently. Higher total cost than Badlands.

length.explanation: 65 miles hits the sweet spot ‚Äî long enough to hurt, short enough to finish strong. It's comparable to the 60km/100km options that established Flandres events offer. Not an epic sufferfest, not a casual spin, just proper gravel distance that respects your time. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: 3500 feet over 65 miles suggests rolling terrain rather than technical punishment. Belgium's Flanders region offers cobbles and farm roads but nothing approaching mountain bike difficulty. You'll get some 'gripets' style steep sections but this isn't a technical skills test. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: 3500 feet over 65 miles averages out to gentle rolling ‚Äî way less demanding than events posting 1100m over 100km. Belgium's highest point is under 700 meters, so you're dealing with punchy climbs rather than sustained suffering. Decent workout, not a mountainous beatdown. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 70¬∞F and lows of 54¬∞F, with a 48% chance of rain on any given day, and gusts reaching 27 mph. Belgium serves up proper cycling weather ‚Äî cool, often damp, occasionally brutal. You'll get that authentic Northern European gravel experience without extreme heat or altitude complications. Weather adds character rather than creating dangerous conditions, assuming you dress for Belgian unpredictability. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Belgium is basically sea level with delusions of grandeur. The entire country peaks under 700 meters, so altitude impact is nonexistent. Your lungs won't notice the difference, your legs will do all the complaining. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds ‚Äî no thin-air concerns.

logistics.explanation: Belgium is compact and well-connected ‚Äî airports, trains, roads all function properly. Flanders region has solid infrastructure even if this specific race hasn't published detailed logistics. The country is small enough that you can't really get lost for long, unlike trying to navigate rural France.

adventure.explanation: This feels more like regional cycling tourism than adventure. Belgium's countryside is pleasant but predictable ‚Äî you're not discovering hidden gems or tackling unknown terrain. It's solid gravel riding through familiar European landscapes without the edge that makes races memorable.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

youtube_data.search_query: Gravel des Flandres gravel race Flanders

videos.title: Dirt, Cobbles & Cake Theft?! | Gravel Tour Of Flanders
videos.description:
The Tour of Flanders, or De Ronde van Vlaanderen, is a race adored by many, and now there's a gravel edition, where you can ride on the cobbles, rough terrain and the infamous Koppenberg, with its 22% maximum gradient! Shimano invited Alex to have a go at the 160km route, but will he have what it takes to ride the whole thing?

In association with Shimano üëâ https://bike.shimano.com/

See the routes on Komoot!  üëâ 
https://www.komoot.com/tour/524050854
https://www.komoot.com/tour/530306618

Subscribe to GCN+ for cycling as you have never seen it before! Live racing, shows & cycling adventure films: https://gcn.eu/plus

Check out the GCN App: 
https://gcn.eu/app

Visit the GCN Shop - Shop Now: https://gcn.eu/6BF
Subscribe to GCN: http://gcn.eu/SubscribeToGCN
Register your interest in the GCN Club: https://gcn.eu/6BE
#Cycling #GCN #RoadBike 

Do you want to ride the Tour of Flanders Gravel? Let us know in the comments! üëá

Sign up to the GCN newsletter https://gcn.eu/3K7
Join our Facebook community: http://gcn.eu/FBCommunity 

If you enjoyed this video, make sure to give it a thumbs up and share it with your friends. üëç

Watch more on GCN...
üìπ  Halfway to Hero: How Fit Is Our Beginner Now? | Ep. 2 üëâ https://gcn.eu/6BD

The Global Cycling Network (GCN) is the largest and fastest-growing online cycling channel in the world, bringing together a global community of road cyclists to celebrate everything that‚Äôs great about the world of cycling. 

Our videos bring fans compelling daily content including expert tutorials, techniques, training, racing, cutting-edge bike tech, unparalleled behind the scenes event coverage, humour,  entertainment, and more. 

Presented by ex-pro riders, GCN offers a uniquely qualified insight into the world of cycling, and most importantly it‚Äôs fuelled by our passionate and enthusiastic fans ‚Äì everyone who makes up the GCN community. We also bring you the latest and greatest tech to your attention, showcase the best places in the world to ride and get exclusive access to events and races.

videos.curation_reason: Comprehensive first-person race experience covering the full 160km gravel event with detailed course insights and race atmosphere.

videos.title: The Alternative: Tour of Flanders, gravel edition | SHIMANO
videos.description:
Subtitles available! Click on the CC (closed captions) button below the video.

Flanders is famous for many things: tales of hard men and legendary riders in ‚ÄòDe Ronde‚Äô battling the elements by bike, fearsome stories of the legendary cobbled ‚Äòmuurs‚Äô that break riders, or, further back in history the fields of Flanders provided a grim backdrop to the devastation of WW1. Flanders is awash with stories and for this reason it was an ideal playground for an alternative gravel exploration for Live Slow Ride Fast podcasters Laurens Ten Dam and Stefan Bolt, plus gravel event organizer Paul Errington. 

Keep in touch with everything we do at:
Website: https://gravel.shimano.com
Instagram: https://instagram.com/ShimanoGravel
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/ShimanoRoad 
Twitter: https://www.twitter.com/ShimanoRoad

Musicbed SyncID:
MB01RQLP1RITX2A

videos.curation_reason: High-quality production showcasing the gravel alternative to the classic Tour of Flanders with detailed route exploration.

videos.title: Flanders Gravel Series 2023 | Relive the first edition of Flanders Gravel Kemmelberg
videos.description:
Cobbles, vineyards, gravel and climbs. The participants were rocking the Kemmelberg area! üòé 
#FlandersGravel #MonumentalMemories #FLCS

videos.title: Gravel & Coffee @ Pedaleur de Flandres
videos.description: After our obligatory COVID19 break, June 28 2020 Gravel & Coffee did roll out again, in search for good gravel roads. Pedaleur de Flanderes was our meeting point. After the ride I had my first experiment for the Coffee Conversations, a Dutch podcast that is now recorded monthly after the ride. ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ev6_7YnCIiE )

videos.title: How To Win The Tour Of Flanders
videos.description:
Join Dan Lloyd on a ride through time as he traces the story and impact of the greatest one-day race in the world: the Ronde van Vlaanderen. Dan meets multiple winners like Stijn Devolder and Johan Museeuw, current top pros like Oliver Naesen, and local journalists, historians and sports directors on his ride up, down and around Belgium‚Äôs infamous cobbled climbs. His goal? To find out how to win the Tour of Flanders.

Sign up for GCN+ now: https://gcn.eu/plus
____________________
GCN+ is the home of the world‚Äôs most thrilling live bike races, highlights, exclusive shows and epic cycling documentaries that you can enjoy live + ad-free + on-demand + interactive + all-year round. 
 
GCN+ is more of everything you‚Äôve come to love from GCN but taken to the next level: more entertainment, more races, more inspiration, more access, more analysis, more science and more to watch with exclusive and original long-form films, documentaries and shows.
 
GCN+ is #cycling like you‚Äôve never seen it before.

quotes.text: This is a bike festival with Flemish cobbles, iconic climbs, brilliant gravel roads, Belgium beer and of course great coffee. I'm going to be taking on some of the famous sections from the race including the patberg and finishing on the brutal Cobble climb of the Koppenberg.

The first day I wanted to build around the route from out an honor and then we enter the prestige - those are the streets where the big battles were for years during World War one, and then I wanted to climb the Kemmel of course which is the most famous mountain of Flanders.

key_challenges.name: Paterberg
key_challenges.description: One of the famous sections from the pro race that riders will encounter on the gravel route.

key_challenges.name: Oude Kwaremont
key_challenges.description: One of the famous sections from the pro race included in the gravel event.

key_challenges.name: Koppenberg
key_challenges.description: The brutal cobble climb where the gravel event finishes.

key_challenges.name: Route Split
key_challenges.description: Easy to miss the split between the 120km and 160km routes if you're not paying attention while chatting in a group.

terrain_notes.text: Features Flemish cobbles mixed with brilliant gravel roads, including some of the same iconic cobbled climbs from the pro Tour of Flanders race.

race_day_tips.text: Pay close attention at route splits, especially around the 40km mark where the 120km and 160km routes diverge - it's easy to miss while chatting in a group.
Sign on early as there are limited breakfast options near the venue, and most shops are closed due to the early morning start time.
Prepare for cold morning conditions - temperatures can be around 4 degrees Celsius at 9:00 AM start time.

additional_quotes.text: I've collected my race number also I've got my voucher here for lunch and a nice little beer at the end of the day
Due to the early event start, there's nothing open again for breakfast options, so you have to make do with whatever you brought

rider_intel.search_text: Gravel des Flandres is organized by the same team behind the pro Tour of Flanders race, featuring iconic Flemish cobbles and brilliant gravel roads. The event includes famous sections from the pro race including Oude Kwaremont, Paterberg, and finishes on the brutal cobble climb of Koppenberg. Riders face multiple distance options with splits that are easy to miss if not paying attention. Morning conditions can be quite cold with temperatures around 4 degrees Celsius at the 9:00 AM start. The event village is located in the center of Oudenaarde with early sign-on recommended due to limited breakfast options. Post-race amenities include lunch vouchers and beer. The course combines the heritage and culture of classic Belgian cycling with modern gravel racing, creating a challenging mix of cobbled climbs and gravel terrain.

photos.alt: Cyclist in red GCN jersey standing on cobblestone road with green agricultural fields and rolling countryside in background during Gravel Des Flandres race - Flanders, Belgium
Close-up selfie of cyclist in red racing kit with sunglasses riding through rural Belgian countryside with tree-lined roads - Gravel des Flandres - Flanders, Belgium
Cyclists preparing bikes in historic Belgian town square with Gothic cathedral and traditional Flemish architecture visible in background - Gravel des Flandres - Flanders, Belgium
Course preview from Gravel Des Flandres race footage
